headline: Instruments of a Beating Heart

lead_paragraph: A look into the Japanese educational system’s delicate balance between teamwork, discipline and personal growth.
snippet: A look into the Japanese educational system’s delicate balance between teamwork, discipline and personal growth.

headline: What a School Performance Shows Us About Japanese Education
abstract: A look into the Japanese educational system’s delicate balancing of teamwork, discipline and personal growth.
lead_paragraph: What makes Japanese people distinctively Japanese? For me, the key lies in what we are taught during our elementary school years.
snippet: A look into the Japanese educational system’s delicate balancing of teamwork, discipline and personal growth.

headline: The Dollar Still Has Its Mojo. X, Not So Much.
abstract: Ruining a network is hard, but Elon Musk shows it’s possible.
lead_paragraph: “There is a great deal of ruin in a network,” Adam Smith once observed.
snippet: Ruining a network is hard, but Elon Musk shows it’s possible.

headline: Sean Duffy, Fox Stalwart, Gets Trump’s Nod for Transportation Secretary
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump nominated the former representative from Wisconsin to oversee a sprawling agency that includes aviation, rail and transit.
lead_paragraph: A former Wisconsin congressman and Fox Business host, Sean Duffy, was selected by President-elect Donald J. Trump on Monday to lead the Transportation Department.
snippet: President-elect Donald J. Trump nominated the former representative from Wisconsin to oversee a sprawling agency that includes aviation, rail and transit.

headline: Newsom Will Delay His Decision on Clemency for the Menendez Brothers
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said he would hold off deciding whether to grant clemency to Lyle and Erik Menendez until after the incoming Los Angeles County district attorney reviewed the case.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said on Monday that he would not make a decision on granting clemency to Lyle and Erik Menendez, who killed their parents in their Beverly Hills home in 1989, until after the incoming district attorney in Los Angeles County conducted his own review of the case.
snippet: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said he would hold off deciding whether to grant clemency to Lyle and Erik Menendez until after the incoming Los Angeles County district attorney reviewed the case.

headline: Arthur Frommer, 95, Dies; His Guidebooks Opened Travel to the Masses
abstract: After publishing “Europe on 5 Dollars a Day” in 1957, he went on to build an empire of guidebooks, package tours, hotels and other services.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Frommer, who expanded the horizons of postwar Americans and virtually invented the low-budget travel industry with his seminal guidebook, “Europe on 5 Dollars a Day: A Guide to Inexpensive Travel,” which introduced millions to an experience once considered the exclusive domain of the wealthy, died on Monday at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 95.
snippet: After publishing “Europe on 5 Dollars a Day” in 1957, he went on to build an empire of guidebooks, package tours, hotels and other services.

headline: N.Y.C. Helped Migrant Accused of Killing Laken Riley Move to Georgia, Witness Says
abstract: In other testimony, law enforcement witnesses placed the suspect, José Ibarra, at the scene of Ms. Riley’s killing, mainly through cellphone and GPS tracking data.
lead_paragraph: Details of how the Venezuelan migrant charged with killing Laken Riley ended up in Athens, Ga., came into sharper focus on Monday, the second day of a trial that is being closely followed by supporters of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s planned immigration crackdown.
snippet: In other testimony, law enforcement witnesses placed the suspect, José Ibarra, at the scene of Ms. Riley’s killing, mainly through cellphone and GPS tracking data.

headline: Two Bee Gees Drummers Die Within Four Days
abstract: Colin “Smiley” Petersen, 78, was the group’s original drummer, and Dennis Bryon, 76, played during the band’s disco heyday.
lead_paragraph: Two drummers for the Bee Gees — one during the long-running Anglo-Australian pop group’s early days of hit-making ballads, the other during its white-hot disco superstardom — died four days apart, according to posts from a tribute band and former bandmates.
snippet: Colin “Smiley” Petersen, 78, was the group’s original drummer, and Dennis Bryon, 76, played during the band’s disco heyday.

headline: Lawyer Says His Client Testified That She Saw Gaetz Having Sex With Underage Girl
abstract: The lawyer told multiple news outlets about the testimony, before the House Ethics Committee, in which the client described witnessing Matt Gaetz having sex with the girl at a party in 2017.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer representing two women who testified that former Representative Matt Gaetz paid them for sex told multiple news outlets on Monday that one of the women described witnessing Mr. Gaetz having sex with an underage girl at a party in 2017.
snippet: The lawyer told multiple news outlets about the testimony, before the House Ethics Committee, in which the client described witnessing Matt Gaetz having sex with the girl at a party in 2017.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 19, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 19, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about the possible tension between Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s agenda against Big Food and President-elect Donald J. Trump’s corporate-friendly goals described incorrectly Mr. Kennedy’s recent comments on Froot Loops. He was comparing the total number of ingredients in the U.S. and Canadian versions of the cereal, not the number of artificial ingredients.
snippet: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 19, 2024.

headline: Dozens of Hong Kong Pro-Democracy Leaders Are Jailed Up to 10 Years
abstract: The 45 defendants, including Joshua Wong, were at the forefront of the opposition movement crushed by Beijing. Many had already been in jail for years.
lead_paragraph: Anywhere else, it wouldn’t have been controversial: a public vote by pro-democracy activists trying to strengthen their hand in legislative elections, to decide who should run. More than 600,000 people took part in the peaceful, unofficial poll.
snippet: The 45 defendants, including Joshua Wong, were at the forefront of the opposition movement crushed by Beijing. Many had already been in jail for years.

headline: Wyoming’s Abortion Bans Are Unconstitutional, Judge Rules
abstract: The ruling found that two state laws — one barring use of abortion pills, and one banning all forms of abortion — violated the state Constitution’s “fundamental right to make health care decisions.”
lead_paragraph: A Wyoming judge ruled on Monday that two state abortion bans — including the first state law specifically banning the use of pills for abortion — violated the Wyoming Constitution and could not be enforced.
snippet: The ruling found that two state laws — one barring use of abortion pills, and one banning all forms of abortion — violated the state Constitution’s “fundamental right to make health care decisions.”

headline: Head Over Heels
abstract: Erik Agard runs down the clock.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
snippet: Erik Agard runs down the clock.

headline: Review: Everyone at the Party Sees Your Texts. A New Play Revels in the Chaos.
abstract: Neil Patrick Harris, Jane Krakowski, Debra Messing and Constance Wu star in the vulgar and entertaining new work from Robert O’Hara.
lead_paragraph: The script to Robert O’Hara’s new play is prefaced with a trigger warning: “This play is a blistering vulgar satire on Male Toxicity and White Privilege.”
snippet: Neil Patrick Harris, Jane Krakowski, Debra Messing and Constance Wu star in the vulgar and entertaining new work from Robert O’Hara.

headline: Uncertainty for Loved Ones of Hong Kong’s Pro-Democracy Activists
abstract: Ventus Lau is one of 45 activists and politicians who was sentenced in the city’s biggest national security trial. His girlfriend, Emilia Wong, a gender rights activist, talks about the impact his case has had on their relationship.
lead_paragraph: Ventus Lau is one of 45 activists and politicians who was sentenced in the city’s biggest national security trial. His girlfriend, Emilia Wong, a gender rights activist, talks about the impact his case has had on their relationship.
snippet: Ventus Lau is one of 45 activists and politicians who was sentenced in the city’s biggest national security trial. His girlfriend, Emilia Wong, a gender rights activist, talks about the impact his case has had on their relationship.

headline: New Zealand Veers Sharply Right, Leaving Jacinda Ardern’s Era Behind
abstract: Two small populist parties are responsible for accelerating the shift, which has been felt acutely by the Indigenous Māori.
lead_paragraph: A year before American voters’ anger over the cost of living helped Donald J. Trump win the presidency, similar sentiments in New Zealand thrust in the nation’s most conservative government in decades.
snippet: Two small populist parties are responsible for accelerating the shift, which has been felt acutely by the Indigenous Māori.

headline: Quote of the Day: Beguiling but Bedraggled, A Pink Sentinel by the Sea Gets a Reprieve, for Now
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 19, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I always saw her as a ballerina, sitting in the marsh alone in her tattered tutu.”
snippet: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 19, 2024.

headline: Russia Has Suffered Colossal Losses in Ukraine. Is Its Army Depleted?
abstract: Researchers and journalists have found innovative ways to measure Russia’s ability to keep fighting.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s military made its largest territorial gains in more than two years in October, as it pressed farther into Ukraine’s eastern Donbas region — but at a heavy cost.
snippet: Researchers and journalists have found innovative ways to measure Russia’s ability to keep fighting.

headline: The Scandinavian Soft Rock Band That’s Big in Asia
abstract: Michael Learns to Rock hoped for success west of their native Denmark. But for 30 years, they’ve had a devoted following on the other side of the world.
lead_paragraph: They have had the kind of career most bands can only dream of: songs that have been downloaded more than a billion times, 11 million records sold and thousands of fans in dozens of cities.
snippet: Michael Learns to Rock hoped for success west of their native Denmark. But for 30 years, they’ve had a devoted following on the other side of the world.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Ukraine’s new military powers.
lead_paragraph: For at least the next two months, Ukraine will be able to try long-range strikes inside Russia using missiles provided by the U.S.
snippet: Ukraine’s new military powers.

headline: Bob Love, Rugged, High-Scoring All-Star for Chicago Bulls, Dies at 81
abstract: Love was a cornerstone of the franchise’s success in the early 1970s. He struggled with a stutter that he overcame only after his playing days were over.
lead_paragraph: Bob Love, a cornerstone player for the ascendant Chicago Bulls during the first half of the 1970s who overcame an enervating stutter after his playing days to work for the team as a motivational speaker, died on Monday in Chicago. He was 81.
snippet: Love was a cornerstone of the franchise’s success in the early 1970s. He struggled with a stutter that he overcame only after his playing days were over.

headline: Putin Sees America Hurtling to Disaster, With Trump at the Wheel
abstract: To the Kremlin, the president-elect is a harbinger of American collapse.
lead_paragraph: The American election results were received with enthusiasm in Moscow. President Vladimir Putin, offering his congratulations, seemed genuinely pleased. But it’s not because Donald Trump is seen as a pro-Russian politician or even one of their own — those illusions faded long ago. Nor is it the prospect of an advantageous peace deal in Ukraine, ruthlessly brokered by Mr. Trump. The first reported call between the two leaders, which the Kremlin denies took place, suggests that the incoming administration will be no pushover.
snippet: To the Kremlin, the president-elect is a harbinger of American collapse.

headline: Word of the Day: mischievous
abstract: This word has appeared in 141 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word mischievous has appeared in 141 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 7 in “Mr. Greedy, Father to Many African Penguins at Maryland Zoo, Dies at 33” by Hank Sanders:
snippet: This word has appeared in 141 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

headline: Maori Protesters Lead March to New Zealand’s Parliament
abstract: Protesters dressed in traditional Māori attire performed hakas while marching alongside tens of thousands of people through the streets of the nation’s capital, Wellington, on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Protesters dressed in traditional Māori attire performed hakas while marching alongside tens of thousands of people through the streets of the nation’s capital, Wellington, on Tuesday.
snippet: Protesters dressed in traditional Māori attire performed hakas while marching alongside tens of thousands of people through the streets of the nation’s capital, Wellington, on Tuesday.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
snippet: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.

headline: Robots Struggle to Match Warehouse Workers on ‘Really Hard’ Jobs
abstract: The machines can load and unload trucks, move goods and do other repetitive tasks but are stymied by some, like picking items from a pile.
lead_paragraph: In the outbound dock of an Amazon warehouse near Nashville, a robotic arm named Cardinal on a recent day stacked packages, Tetris-style, into six-and-a-half-foot-high carts. Then Proteus, an autonomous platform, moved the carts to the loading bay, flashing electronic eyes designed to make the robot more appealing to human colleagues.
snippet: The machines can load and unload trucks, move goods and do other repetitive tasks but are stymied by some, like picking items from a pile.

headline: Where Glaciers Melt, the Rivers Run Red
abstract: As the glaciers of South America retreat, the supply of freshwater is dwindling and its quality is getting worse.
lead_paragraph: Dionisia Moreno, a 70-year-old Indigenous farmer, still remembers when Shallap River, nearly 13,000 feet up in the Cordillera Blanca, brought crystal clear water brimming with trout to her village, Jancu. “People and animals alike could drink the water without suffering,” she said. “Now the water is red. No one can drink it.”
snippet: As the glaciers of South America retreat, the supply of freshwater is dwindling and its quality is getting worse.

headline: What to Know About the Daniel Penny Trial as the Prosecution Rests
abstract: Prosecutors have had to acknowledge that a victim frightened those around him. The defense lawyers are expected to paint their client as a protector.
lead_paragraph: Over eight days of testimony from more than 30 witnesses, prosecutors have not shied away from accounts that described the homeless man whom Daniel Penny choked to death on an F train as frightening. In fact, they sought them out.
snippet: Prosecutors have had to acknowledge that a victim frightened those around him. The defense lawyers are expected to paint their client as a protector.

headline: Teddy Bear Jeans
abstract: Would you wear 200 stuffed animals? What’s the most interesting outfit you’ve ever worn?
lead_paragraph: How would you describe your fashion style? Do you tend toward the practical, the traditional and the low-key? Or, do you like to dress in bold, flashy and unconventional designs?
snippet: Would you wear 200 stuffed animals? What’s the most interesting outfit you’ve ever worn?

headline: An Affordable Housing Project Faced a Huge Backlash. It Won Anyway.
abstract: A developer wanted to replace parking garages with affordable apartments in Manhattan, but some residents on the Upper West Side resisted. Here’s why the housing won.
lead_paragraph: This is The Housing Crunch, a five-part series on New York City’s affordable housing crisis.
snippet: A developer wanted to replace parking garages with affordable apartments in Manhattan, but some residents on the Upper West Side resisted. Here’s why the housing won.

headline: Late Night Is Appalled by Trump’s Mile-High McDonald’s Feast
abstract: The president-elect dined on his plane with some associates — including Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who hates fast food. Jimmy Kimmel called it a “subservience test.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
snippet: The president-elect dined on his plane with some associates — including Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who hates fast food. Jimmy Kimmel called it a “subservience test.”

headline: China’s Soaring Emissions Are Upending Climate Politics
abstract: China has now passed Europe in its historical contribution to global warming. Rich nations say the country should contribute more climate aid.
lead_paragraph: China has now passed Europe in its historical contribution to global warming. Rich nations say the country should contribute more climate aid.
snippet: China has now passed Europe in its historical contribution to global warming. Rich nations say the country should contribute more climate aid.

headline: The Man Behind the Legendary Donkey Kong Country Soundtracks
abstract: David Wise turbocharged the Super Nintendo for scores inspired by the Glenn Miller Orchestra, Prokofiev, Duran Duran and more.
lead_paragraph: The initial hype about Donkey Kong Country, which was released for the Super Nintendo 30 years ago this week, was centered on its impressive 3-D-ish graphics. But the game’s legacy proved to be its soundtrack.
snippet: David Wise turbocharged the Super Nintendo for scores inspired by the Glenn Miller Orchestra, Prokofiev, Duran Duran and more.

headline: Underground, in the Mud, At Sea: A Reporter Goes Far to Cover Energy
abstract: Electricity has become our most critical resource. Oil is still coveted. The drive for energy has taken one Times reporter all over the map.
lead_paragraph: I cover energy for The New York Times. And you might be surprised by where my beat takes me — from deep inside the earth, as far down as the Empire State Building is tall, to the middle of the Gulf of Mexico on an oil platform that floats 7,000 feet above the ocean floor.
snippet: Electricity has become our most critical resource. Oil is still coveted. The drive for energy has taken one Times reporter all over the map.

headline: Why Do My Ears Hurt on Planes?
abstract: “Airplane ear” can muffle hearing and make your ears feel clogged. Here’s why, and how to avoid it.
lead_paragraph: Q: Sometimes my ears hurt during flights. Why does this happen, and what can I do about it?
snippet: “Airplane ear” can muffle hearing and make your ears feel clogged. Here’s why, and how to avoid it.

headline: Kacey Musgraves’s Nashville
abstract: The country singer and songwriter, up for five Grammy Awards this year, including best country album, recommends spots in her adopted home.
lead_paragraph: “I always knew that Nashville would be a destination of some sort for me, that I would land there in terms of music,” said the singer-songwriter Kacey Musgraves during a Zoom call. A native Texan who is nominated for five Grammys this year, including best country album for “Deeper Well,” her fifth studio album, she began singing at a young age and at 18 competed on season five of the country music television show “Nashville Star.” A year later she moved to Nashville and never looked back. “I do owe so much to the community there for absolutely shaping me and my songs, and for giving me the opportunities that I’ve had,” she said.
snippet: The country singer and songwriter, up for five Grammy Awards this year, including best country album, recommends spots in her adopted home.

headline: Do You Need to Take Magnesium Supplements?
abstract: We looked into what the mineral can — and can’t — do for sleep, mental health and more.
lead_paragraph: Magnesium supplements are said to help with a long list of ailments: sleep problems, migraine headaches, depression, high blood pressure, muscle cramps, constipation. One wellness coach on TikTok went so far as to say that in order “to be a functioning member of society,” everyone should be taking them.
snippet: We looked into what the mineral can — and can’t — do for sleep, mental health and more.

headline: Becoming Cher Didn’t Come Easy
abstract: The first volume of her frank autobiography is a testament to resilience, chronicling a grim childhood and the brazen path to stardom, with and without Sonny.
lead_paragraph: Before Twitter morphed into the strange ghost town of X, with lurking users wondering whether to post or stomping off in high dudgeon for Bluesky and Threads, Cher was one of its finest sheriffs. Publications including The New York Times analyzed her grammar-defying style and compiled her stinging critiques of the then and future president Donald J. Trump.
snippet: The first volume of her frank autobiography is a testament to resilience, chronicling a grim childhood and the brazen path to stardom, with and without Sonny.

headline: 2 Novels Filled With Christmas Miracles
abstract: Two families navigate a pivotal holiday season that transforms their lives.
lead_paragraph: If you are a cynical sort (and who isn’t, these days?), the concept of a novel set around Christmas may fill you with a particular squeamishness and fear of holiday cringe. Predictable festive narratives have been fed to many of us throughout our lives, so it’s only fair to feel some wariness.
snippet: Two families navigate a pivotal holiday season that transforms their lives.

headline: 8 Factors That Put You at Risk of Severe Flu
abstract: Flu infections have started picking up. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: Sore throat. Stuffy nose. Fever, body aches and fatigue. As temperatures drop, cases of the flu have started to rise.
snippet: Flu infections have started picking up. Here’s what to know.

headline: How ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Took Gen Z for a Spin
abstract: After almost 20 years on air, the reality competition series made changes that brought a surge of younger viewers.
lead_paragraph: The world has changed around “Dancing With the Stars” since the competition series became a hit after its 2005 premiere. Though producers have periodically experimented with casting, canned hosts and tweaked the elimination process, the heart of the show — pairs of professional dancers and celebrities performing weekly and facing elimination based on scores from judges and fan votes — has remained intact.
snippet: After almost 20 years on air, the reality competition series made changes that brought a surge of younger viewers.

headline: The Artist, the Gallerist and Their Liver
abstract: Far from the dizzying auctions, splashy galas and angling dealers, a precious gift sheds light on a gentler way the art world works.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Doran was in a desperate place on the evening of Feb. 23, 2023, when she quietly interrupted a celebration that Robischon Gallery was throwing for its 45th anniversary and summoned the artists in attendance to join her in a back room.
snippet: Far from the dizzying auctions, splashy galas and angling dealers, a precious gift sheds light on a gentler way the art world works.

headline: The World Is Watching the U.S. Deal With Bird Flu, and It’s Scary
abstract: The U.S. needs to reassure the world it has the outbreak under control.
lead_paragraph: As a virus scientist in South Africa, I’ve been watching with dread as H5N1 bird flu spreads among animals in the United States. The pathogen poses a serious pandemic threat and has been detected in over 500 dairy herds in 15 states — which is probably an undercount. And yet the U.S. response appears inadequate and slow, with too few genomic sequences of H5N1 cases in farm animals made publicly available for scientific review.
snippet: The U.S. needs to reassure the world it has the outbreak under control.

headline: Robert Frank, a Filmmaker Who Never Stopped Changing
abstract: The photographer renounced his first career to focus on filmmaking. Starting Wednesday, the Museum of Modern Art will stage a cinema retrospective of his uncompromising search for the real.
lead_paragraph: In one of art history’s greatest zigzags, Robert Frank, who would have been 100 this year, renounced photography even before he was famous for it.
snippet: The photographer renounced his first career to focus on filmmaking. Starting Wednesday, the Museum of Modern Art will stage a cinema retrospective of his uncompromising search for the real.

headline: Luigi Nono and the Radical, Urgent Act of Listening
abstract: Born 100 years ago, Nono composed music that demands attention, with a political fervor that remains as essential today as it was in his time.
lead_paragraph: In 1954, Arnold Schoenberg’s widow, Gertrud, and their daughter, Nuria, traveled from the United States to Europe for the first time since fleeing Nazism two decades earlier. They went to Hamburg, Germany, for the concert premiere of Schoenberg’s “Moses und Aron,” where Nuria met the young Italian composer Luigi Nono.
snippet: Born 100 years ago, Nono composed music that demands attention, with a political fervor that remains as essential today as it was in his time.

headline: Ozempic Could Crush the Junk Food Industry. But It Is Fighting Back.
abstract: As revolutionary new weight-loss drugs turn consumers off ultraprocessed foods, the industry is on the hunt for new products.
lead_paragraph: Trinian Taylor, a 52-year-old car dealer, pushed his cart through the aisles of a supermarket as I pretended not to follow him. It was a bright August day in Northern California, and I had come to the store to meet Emily Auerbach, a relationship manager at Mattson, a food-innovation firm that creates products for the country’s largest food and beverage companies: McDonald’s and White Castle, PepsiCo and Hostess. Auerbach was trying to understand the shopping behavior of Ozempic users, and Taylor was one of her case studies. She instructed me to stay as close as I could without influencing his route around the store. In her experience of shop-alongs, too much space, or taking photos, would be a red flag for the supermarket higher-ups, who might figure out we were not here to shop. “They’d be like, ‘You need to exit,’” she said.
snippet: As revolutionary new weight-loss drugs turn consumers off ultraprocessed foods, the industry is on the hunt for new products.

headline: I Liked New York as a Tourist. I Fell In Love With It as a Tour Guide.
abstract: How did pigeons came to dominate our streets? Where did Katharine Hepburn live? The answers might be more interesting than you think.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy December day in 2022, I did what most New Yorkers loathe to do: I took the train to Times Square. I made my way into a testing center used by the New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection, somewhere between Margaritaville and Madame Tussauds. No, I had not been subpoenaed; rather, I was one multiple-choice test away from becoming a licensed sightseeing guide. All I had to do was answer 150 questions about history, architecture and transit in the five boroughs.
snippet: How did pigeons came to dominate our streets? Where did Katharine Hepburn live? The answers might be more interesting than you think.

headline: 4 Colorful Thanksgiving Veggie Sides to Brighten Your Table
abstract: These abundant vegetarian dishes from Melissa Clark aren’t just gorgeous. They’re sure to make everyone at the table happy.
lead_paragraph: The traditional Thanksgiving table generally sticks to a muted, autumnal palette: bland beiges and tans, maybe accentuated by ruddy orange or maroon, and mild flavors to match.
snippet: These abundant vegetarian dishes from Melissa Clark aren’t just gorgeous. They’re sure to make everyone at the table happy.

headline: Jesse Ed Davis Was Rock Heroes’ Secret Weapon. And a Mystery.
abstract: The Native American guitarist graced records by Bob Dylan and John Lennon, but fell to addiction in 1988. A new book and exhibit are telling his story.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1967, the blues singer Taj Mahal was about to cut his first solo album for Columbia Records and needed to find a new guitarist in a hurry. He headed to a bar in Los Angeles’s Topanga Canyon, tipped off about a young Native American musician with a mesmerizing touch on the Telecaster. Having already worked with the guitar prodigy Ry Cooder in the short-lived band the Rising Sons, Mahal had high standards. But it took barely a minute of hearing Jesse Ed Davis to realize he’d found what he was looking for.
snippet: The Native American guitarist graced records by Bob Dylan and John Lennon, but fell to addiction in 1988. A new book and exhibit are telling his story.

headline: For Minority Working-Class Voters, Dismay With Democrats Led to Distrust
abstract: In scores of interviews throughout 2024, Latino, Black and Asian American voters, many of whom voted for Donald Trump, said they no longer trusted Democrats to improve the economy.
lead_paragraph: The working-class voters Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign needed were not moved by talk of joy. They were too angry about feeling broke.
snippet: In scores of interviews throughout 2024, Latino, Black and Asian American voters, many of whom voted for Donald Trump, said they no longer trusted Democrats to improve the economy.

headline: Jon Batiste Can’t Stop Thinking About Beethoven
abstract: Batiste’s latest album is a return to his classical music roots — on his terms. Hear him improvise on some of Beethoven’s classics.
lead_paragraph: Long before Jon Batiste was a bandleader, television personality and Grammy- and Academy Award-winning artist, he was a classical piano student.
snippet: Batiste’s latest album is a return to his classical music roots — on his terms. Hear him improvise on some of Beethoven’s classics.

headline: ‘Interior Chinatown’ Puts Stereotypes in the Spotlight
abstract: Adapted by Charles Yu from his own novel, this series about a man stuck inside a cop show satirizes Hollywood’s penchant for pigeonholing Asian actors.
lead_paragraph: One of Jimmy O. Yang’s first TV roles was Asian Teenager No. 2, in a 2013 episode of “Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.”
snippet: Adapted by Charles Yu from his own novel, this series about a man stuck inside a cop show satirizes Hollywood’s penchant for pigeonholing Asian actors.

headline: The Hypebeasts Take Las Vegas
abstract: ComplexCon, held this year in Nevada and “curated” by Travis Scott, is a mutant hybrid of a sneaker mall, a fashion show and a music festival. And the kids just love it.
lead_paragraph: On the first afternoon of ComplexCon, a head-spinning shoppable trade show, music festival and general meeting of North America’s sneaker zealots, Martin Pawelec stood out in his tucked-in golf polo.
snippet: ComplexCon, held this year in Nevada and “curated” by Travis Scott, is a mutant hybrid of a sneaker mall, a fashion show and a music festival. And the kids just love it.

headline: Orders for Morning-After Pills and Abortion Pills Rise After Trump’s Election
abstract: Some women are stocking up on the medications, saying they are concerned that the new administration could take steps to restrict access.
lead_paragraph: The day after the election, Beth Ryan ordered two packages of emergency contraception pills and had them sent to her 27-year-old daughter.
snippet: Some women are stocking up on the medications, saying they are concerned that the new administration could take steps to restrict access.

headline: Travel Pledged to Help Cut Carbon Emissions. How Has It Done?
abstract: The tourism industry will be officially recognized at COP29 on Wednesday. Industry leaders signed a climate accord in 2021 to make travel more sustainable, but the results so far are meager.
lead_paragraph: In Baku, Azerbaijan, this week, the travel industry will have its first official day ever at the annual United Nations climate talks. At COP29, as this year’s conference is known, Wednesday has been set as a “thematic day on tourism,” and there will be high-level meetings and roundtables devoted to the tourism industry’s effects on the environment and climate change and how they might be mitigated.
snippet: The tourism industry will be officially recognized at COP29 on Wednesday. Industry leaders signed a climate accord in 2021 to make travel more sustainable, but the results so far are meager.

headline: ‘Les Misérables’ Returns Home
abstract: The most famous French musical has never been popular in Paris. A major new production hopes to change that, reworking it for a contemporary French audience.
lead_paragraph: Globally, it’s the most famous French musical. One hundred and thirty million people have seen Jean Valjean face off against Javert, in 22 languages; its downtrodden characters have taken to the barricades in London’s West End nearly continuously since 1985.
snippet: The most famous French musical has never been popular in Paris. A major new production hopes to change that, reworking it for a contemporary French audience.

headline: Dan Osborn Wants to Help the Working Class Run for Office
abstract: Mr. Osborn, the industrial mechanic who turned a long-shot Senate bid in red Nebraska into an unexpectedly tight race, is starting a PAC aimed at recruiting more blue-collar candidates like himself.
lead_paragraph: Dan Osborn, an industrial mechanic who ran as an independent Senate candidate in Nebraska, came up short in his quest to unseat Senator Deb Fischer, a low-profile Republican whose closer-than-expected victory in a red state clinched Senate control for her party on election night.
snippet: Mr. Osborn, the industrial mechanic who turned a long-shot Senate bid in red Nebraska into an unexpectedly tight race, is starting a PAC aimed at recruiting more blue-collar candidates like himself.

headline: Ken Martin, a Minnesotan With Deep Democratic Ties, Joins the D.N.C. Race
abstract: The chairman of Minnesota Democrats, he has longstanding connections to many of the Democratic National Committee members who will choose their next leader.
lead_paragraph: The race for chair of the Democratic National Committee may eventually include candidates who are well known across the party, but few are likely to have deeper relationships with the committee members who have a vote in the contest than Ken Martin, the Minnesota Democratic chairman.
snippet: The chairman of Minnesota Democrats, he has longstanding connections to many of the Democratic National Committee members who will choose their next leader.

headline: Trump Kicks Down the Guardrails
abstract: Anne Applebaum on how to think about autocracy and authoritarianism in a second Trump term.
lead_paragraph: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: Anne Applebaum on how to think about autocracy and authoritarianism in a second Trump term.

headline: 5 Ways R.F.K. Jr. Could Undermine Lifesaving Childhood Vaccines
abstract: If he is confirmed as H.H.S. secretary, the longtime vaccine critic would be in a position to change the government’s immunization recommendations and delay the development of new vaccines.
lead_paragraph: For years, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., has leveraged his famous name, his celebrity connections and his nonprofit, Children’s Health Defense, to spread misinformation about vaccines and call their safety and efficacy into question. Soon, he might have the power to go much further.
snippet: If he is confirmed as H.H.S. secretary, the longtime vaccine critic would be in a position to change the government’s immunization recommendations and delay the development of new vaccines.

headline: Trump’s Win Terrifies Me. Why Don’t Boys My Age Care?
abstract: Naomi Beinart, 16, on the gender divide that the election revealed at her high school.
lead_paragraph: Exit polls from the presidential election reveal a divided country: Women tended to vote for Kamala Harris; men, for Donald Trump. And that divide may extend to citizens who aren’t yet of voting age. Naomi Beinart, a 16-year-old junior, witnessed it at her school in the days after the election. In this episode, Beinart says that while her fellow female students fear for the future, “this election didn’t seem to measurably change anything for the boys around me, whether their parents supported Mr. Trump or not.”
snippet: Naomi Beinart, 16, on the gender divide that the election revealed at her high school.

headline: Magicians Mount Search for Woman Behind Decades-Old Deception
abstract: A British society of magicians expelled a woman for tricking her way into the club in 1991. Now it wants to invite her back, but the woman seems to have pulled a disappearing act.
lead_paragraph: The greatest trick that “Raymond Lloyd” may ever have performed was a complex illusion: Convincing an elite, male-only society of magicians that he existed.
snippet: A British society of magicians expelled a woman for tricking her way into the club in 1991. Now it wants to invite her back, but the woman seems to have pulled a disappearing act.

headline: Wearing Your Personality on Your Handbag
abstract: Bag charms — or key chains by another name — have begun to rival holiday ornaments in their variety and as a form of self-expression.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy enough to picture a blue button-up shirt, a pleated mini skirt and ballet flats on a person. Now imagine the outfit on a bag.
snippet: Bag charms — or key chains by another name — have begun to rival holiday ornaments in their variety and as a form of self-expression.

headline: How to Make Central Park Safer for Pedestrians
abstract: A report from the Central Park Conservancy recommends changes in the park’s roads to protect walkers from fast-moving cyclists.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll find out about new recommendations for the roads that loop through Central Park. We’ll also look at data showing that one in eight students in the city’s public school system was homeless last year.
snippet: A report from the Central Park Conservancy recommends changes in the park’s roads to protect walkers from fast-moving cyclists.

headline: Polling Is Not the Problem
abstract: Why it can’t fix our messy politics.
lead_paragraph: The polls just can’t win in the court of public opinion — the very thing they’re designed to study.
snippet: Why it can’t fix our messy politics.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 528
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Nov. 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Nov. 20, 2024.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,250
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 20, 2024.

headline: Explosive Claims About Gaetz, and Dozens Jailed in Hong Kong Mass Trial
abstract: Plus, the man who opened travel to the masses.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:
snippet: Plus, the man who opened travel to the masses.

headline: Editors’ Note
abstract: This article was published prematurely.
snippet: This article was published prematurely.

headline: From Resistance to Reflection
abstract: When Donald Trump won the presidency in 2016, it prompted an outpouring of protests. What will happen this time?
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains strong language.
snippet: When Donald Trump won the presidency in 2016, it prompted an outpouring of protests. What will happen this time?

headline: Man Drives Car Into Crowd Outside Primary School in China
abstract: The incident followed an attack by a driver last week that left 35 people dead, and a mass stabbing several days later.
lead_paragraph: A man drove a car into a group of people near an elementary school in central China on Tuesday, injuring multiple students, in what appeared to be the third large-scale attack in the country in a little over a week.
snippet: The incident followed an attack by a driver last week that left 35 people dead, and a mass stabbing several days later.

headline: U.K. Farmers Protest in London Over Inheritance Tax Change
abstract: Farms worth more than about $1.3 million will face an estate tax from 2026, ending a previous exemption and prompting anger in some rural communities.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of farmers gathered in central London on Tuesday in the biggest show of opposition to a policy announced by Britain’s center-left Labour government since it won power in July.
snippet: Farms worth more than about $1.3 million will face an estate tax from 2026, ending a previous exemption and prompting anger in some rural communities.

headline: Putin Lowers Russia’s Threshold for Using Nuclear Arms
abstract: A decree signed by the Russian leader, though long planned, came days after President Biden authorized the use of U.S.-supplied  missiles by Ukraine for strikes inside Russia.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin on Tuesday lowered Russia’s threshold for the use of nuclear weapons, a long-planned move whose timing appeared designed to show the Kremlin could respond aggressively to Ukrainian strikes on Russian territory with American missiles.
snippet: A decree signed by the Russian leader, though long planned, came days after President Biden authorized the use of U.S.-supplied  missiles by Ukraine for strikes inside Russia.

headline: What’s Killing Kids?
abstract: We explore America’s childhood death rate.
lead_paragraph: If I drew you a graph that showed the death rate among American kids, you would see a backward check mark: Fewer kids died over the last several decades, thanks to everything from leukemia drugs to bicycle helmets. Then, suddenly, came a reversal.
snippet: We explore America’s childhood death rate.

headline: U.S. Envoy Signals Progress in Israel-Hezbollah Talks as War Intensifies
abstract: The envoy, Amos Hochstein, said an end to the fighting was “within our grasp” after meeting in Beirut with Lebanon’s Parliament speaker, a key interlocutor with Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: A top U.S. envoy to the Middle East on Tuesday signaled progress in negotiations between Israel and Hezbollah on a cease-fire proposal that, if agreed upon, could ease hostilities in a region already on edge over Israel’s war in Gaza.
snippet: The envoy, Amos Hochstein, said an end to the fighting was “within our grasp” after meeting in Beirut with Lebanon’s Parliament speaker, a key interlocutor with Hezbollah.

headline: Severing of Baltic Sea Cables Was ‘Sabotage,’ Germany Says
abstract: Germany’s defense minister said damage to two fiber-optic cables on the sea floor appeared deliberate, but a culprit was not known.
lead_paragraph: Germany’s defense minister on Tuesday called the severing of two fiber-optic cables in the Baltic Sea an act of sabotage aimed at European countries that are supporting Ukraine in its war against Russia.
snippet: Germany’s defense minister said damage to two fiber-optic cables on the sea floor appeared deliberate, but a culprit was not known.

headline: What Special Community Rituals and Traditions Does Your Hometown Have?
abstract: Every year, Santa Fe, N.M., incinerates a giant puppet of Zozobra in a ritual meant to purge anxiety and promote a reset.
lead_paragraph: What’s unique or special about your hometown? Are there any community rituals or traditions that bring residents together? Are there annual events that you would recommend to outsiders?
snippet: Every year, Santa Fe, N.M., incinerates a giant puppet of Zozobra in a ritual meant to purge anxiety and promote a reset.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: Republican Win, Obesity Report, Rhesus Monkeys
abstract: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
snippet: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: Walmart Sees ‘Momentum’ Ahead of Holiday Shopping Season
abstract: The bellwether retailer reported higher-than-expected sales in its latest quarter and upgraded its forecast for the rest of the year.
lead_paragraph: Walmart has told its workers that it plans to “win” the holiday season. Ahead of the peak shopping period, the nation’s largest retailer appears well positioned, citing “broad-based strength” across its product range.
snippet: The bellwether retailer reported higher-than-expected sales in its latest quarter and upgraded its forecast for the rest of the year.

headline: Is the Biden Administration Coming for Chrome?
abstract: The Justice Department is reportedly targeting Google’s web browser as its antitrust enforcers seek to cement a major win before Donald Trump takes office.
lead_paragraph: Before the Biden administration’s antitrust leaders step down, they’re taking their final shots at Big Tech. That will reportedly include an effort to break up Google as a consequence of the Justice Department’s successful competition lawsuit against the company.
snippet: The Justice Department is reportedly targeting Google’s web browser as its antitrust enforcers seek to cement a major win before Donald Trump takes office.

headline: Ukraine Fired U.S.-Made Missiles Into Russia for First Time, Officials Say
abstract: The attack came just days after President Biden gave Ukraine permission to use the weapons to strike targets inside Russia.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s military used American-made ballistic missiles on Tuesday to strike into Russia for the first time, according to senior U.S. and Ukrainian officials, just days after President Biden gave permission to do so in a major shift of American policy.
snippet: The attack came just days after President Biden gave Ukraine permission to use the weapons to strike targets inside Russia.

headline: ‘Barbenheimer’ Ruled the Box Office. Can ‘Glicked’ Recapture the Magic?
abstract: “Wicked” and “Gladiator II” both open Friday, and some fans hope to rekindle the excitement that greeted last year’s simultaneous openings of “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer.”
lead_paragraph: The summer of 2023 was all about “Barbenheimer” — when “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” opened the same day, capturing the public imagination and bringing crowds back to movie theaters that had struggled since the pandemic.
snippet: “Wicked” and “Gladiator II” both open Friday, and some fans hope to rekindle the excitement that greeted last year’s simultaneous openings of “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer.”

headline: They Taught A.I. to Sing, and It Was Beautiful
abstract: Holly Herndon and Mat Dryhurst are presenting their first large-scale solo museum show. It sounds gorgeous, even if its visual elements are lacking.
lead_paragraph: Although it’s easy to feel alienated by the opaque processes behind artificial intelligence and fearful that the technology isn’t regulated, the artists Holly Herndon and Mat Dryhurst want you to know that A.I. can be beautiful.
snippet: Holly Herndon and Mat Dryhurst are presenting their first large-scale solo museum show. It sounds gorgeous, even if its visual elements are lacking.

headline: Trump, the Military and Plans for Mass Deportation
abstract: Questions about the president-elect’s plan, and a call for protests. Also: Tears after the election; funds for education; a roofless stadium in Buffalo.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
snippet: Questions about the president-elect’s plan, and a call for protests. Also: Tears after the election; funds for education; a roofless stadium in Buffalo.

headline: Hacker Is Said to Have Gained Access to File With Damaging Testimony About Gaetz
abstract: The computer file is said to contain testimony from the woman who said she had sex with Matt Gaetz, President-elect Donald Trump’s choice to be attorney general, when she was 17.
lead_paragraph: An unidentified hacker has gained access to a computer file shared in a secure link among lawyers whose clients have given damaging testimony related to Matt Gaetz, the former Florida congressman who is President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice to be attorney general, a person with knowledge of the activity said.
snippet: The computer file is said to contain testimony from the woman who said she had sex with Matt Gaetz, President-elect Donald Trump’s choice to be attorney general, when she was 17.

headline: ‘Excuse Me! How Much Do You Pay for Rent in New York?’
abstract: When we asked the online celeb Caleb Simpson if he would give us a tour of his house, he said “Yes.” Here’s what we found.
lead_paragraph: Caleb Simpson began his quest to get ordinary New Yorkers to give him a tour of their apartments with an iPhone and a man-on-the-street persona about two years ago. He would spontaneously walk up to random people on the street, asking if they owned or rented their apartment, and how much they paid per month. If they told him — which was rare — he would ask if he could see their home, which he then wanted to post on his social platforms.
snippet: When we asked the online celeb Caleb Simpson if he would give us a tour of his house, he said “Yes.” Here’s what we found.

headline: Trump Defies the #MeToo Movement With Cabinet Picks Facing Accusations
abstract: Donald J. Trump, who was found liable for sexual abuse last year, appears determined to force a fight over the role of such allegations in society.
lead_paragraph: When he takes the oath of office in January, Donald J. Trump will make history as the first court-adjudicated sexual abuser to assume the presidency. But if he gets the team of his choice, he will not be the only one in the room whose conduct has been called into question.
snippet: Donald J. Trump, who was found liable for sexual abuse last year, appears determined to force a fight over the role of such allegations in society.

headline: How Trump’s Tax Cuts and Tariffs Could Turn Into Law
abstract: Republicans are juggling complex political and tactical questions as they plan their congressional agenda next year.
lead_paragraph: Republicans are starting to sketch out how to translate President-elect Donald J. Trump’s economic agenda into law, putting plans in place to bypass Democrats and approve multiple bills reshaping the nation’s tax and spending policies along party lines.
snippet: Republicans are juggling complex political and tactical questions as they plan their congressional agenda next year.

headline: As French Rape Trial Nears End, Wife Speaks of ‘Banality’ and ‘Cowardice’
abstract: Gisèle Pelicot made her final address to the court, calling the things her husband allegedly did to her “unforgivable.”
lead_paragraph: For more than 10 weeks, Gisèle Pelicot has sat in a courtroom in Avignon, France, quietly listening to the explanations of 50 men, including her now ex-husband, charged with raping, sexually assaulting or attempting to rape her while she was in an unconscious state, having been drugged by her husband.
snippet: Gisèle Pelicot made her final address to the court, calling the things her husband allegedly did to her “unforgivable.”

headline: A Fast, French-y Chicken Dinner
abstract: Chicken au poivre is a fancy-feeling take on a velvety French classic.
lead_paragraph: What do you cook when you decide to do something nice for yourself for dinner, something a little fancy — or that just feels a little fancy? I know what I’ll be making next time: our new recipe for chicken au poivre, a steakless version of the irresistibly peppery classic. Serve it with egg noodles, a green salad and a bottle of red wine. Be good to yourself! You’re worth it!
snippet: Chicken au poivre is a fancy-feeling take on a velvety French classic.

headline: Delhi Trudges Through Another Air Pollution Nightmare With No Answers
abstract: The government seems powerless to protect its citizens from this annual crisis, let alone prevent it.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning, the air quality in India’s capital under a widely used index stood at 485. While that is almost five times the threshold for healthy breathing, it felt like a relief: The day before, the reading had shot up to 1,785. Infinitesimal air particles were still clogging lungs and arteries, but it was possible to see sunlight again, and to smell things.
snippet: The government seems powerless to protect its citizens from this annual crisis, let alone prevent it.

headline: Trump’s Treasury Challenge: A Pick Who Loves Tariffs Yet Calms Markets
abstract: The president-elect is considering a conflicting mix of qualities as he decides who will steer his economic agenda.
lead_paragraph: The conflicting goals of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s economic agenda have been playing out as he debates whom to choose as his Treasury secretary, a job that will entail steering tax cuts through Congress, leading trade talks with China and overseeing the $30 trillion U.S. bond market.
snippet: The president-elect is considering a conflicting mix of qualities as he decides who will steer his economic agenda.

headline: SpaceX Starship Launch Ends With a Dramatic Water Landing
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump joined Elon Musk, as his company’s prototype moon and Mars rocket carried out a sixth test flight that showed a mix of progress and setbacks.
lead_paragraph: SpaceX’s latest test flight of its Starship vehicle on Tuesday got off to a sobering start, as the company was unable to recover the enormous booster stage of the rocket, the most powerful ever built. But about an hour later, the vehicle’s upper stage was more successful with the completion of a daring maneuver to splash down in the Indian Ocean.
snippet: President-elect Donald J. Trump joined Elon Musk, as his company’s prototype moon and Mars rocket carried out a sixth test flight that showed a mix of progress and setbacks.

headline: The Perfect Novel for the Baku Climate Summit
abstract: The U.N. climate conference, held in a petrostate, is a surreal moment. This darkly funny novel about Baku, oil companies and climate change in the first Trump term helps make sense of it all.
lead_paragraph: The irony is extreme: This year’s annual United Nations climate change summit is in Baku, Azerbaijan, the petrostate where the modern oil industry was born.
snippet: The U.N. climate conference, held in a petrostate, is a surreal moment. This darkly funny novel about Baku, oil companies and climate change in the first Trump term helps make sense of it all.

headline: Daniel Boulud Opens La Tête d’Or, His First Steakhouse
abstract: Melissa Rodriguez opens Crane Club in the Al Coro space, the Anton’s team take on all-day Italian at Leon’s and more.
lead_paragraph: The centerpiece in the plush, bronzed and soaring dining room of Daniel Boulud’s first steakhouse is an impressive two-level grill fueled with charcoal and wood that sits in an open kitchen. Its marble counter frequently bears a display of steaks, from a tomahawk with its flying buttress bone, to compact portions of densely marbled Wagyu, all to be served with choices of butters and sauces. “I’ve always had a steak or two on my menus, but not eight or 10 like here,” Mr. Boulud said. French touches dapple the varied menu that includes sweetbreads, grilled langoustines and sundaes. The 120-seat dining room provides some more intimate areas, including an elegant bar.
snippet: Melissa Rodriguez opens Crane Club in the Al Coro space, the Anton’s team take on all-day Italian at Leon’s and more.

headline: Lula Was Target of Assassination Plot, Brazilian Police Say
abstract: Members of an elite army unit planned to kill Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva in 2022 as part of an effort to keep Jair Bolsonaro in power after he lost the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Brazilian authorities arrested several members of an elite Brazilian army unit on Tuesday, accusing them of planning to assassinate Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva in 2022, shortly before he was to become the country’s president, as part of a plot to keep the far-right incumbent president, Jair Bolsonaro, in power.
snippet: Members of an elite army unit planned to kill Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva in 2022 as part of an effort to keep Jair Bolsonaro in power after he lost the presidential election.

headline: Disillusioned by the Election, Some Black Women Are Deciding to Rest
abstract: Instead of charging to the front lines of the culture wars, many Black women have vowed to prioritize their own well-being first.
lead_paragraph: Cheri Hall woke up hours before dawn the morning after Election Day and checked her phone anxiously for results. A news notification hinting that former President Donald J. Trump had defeated Vice President Kamala Harris caused her to gasp and grab her chest.
snippet: Instead of charging to the front lines of the culture wars, many Black women have vowed to prioritize their own well-being first.

headline: Manhattan D.A. Suggests Freezing Trump’s Case While He Is President
abstract: With President-elect Donald J. Trump’s sentencing on hold, his lawyers are pushing to dismiss the case. The district attorney, Alvin L. Bragg, is opposing the effort.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan prosecutors on Tuesday rebuffed President-elect Donald J. Trump’s request to dismiss his criminal conviction in the wake of his electoral victory, signaling instead their willingness to freeze the case while he holds office.
snippet: With President-elect Donald J. Trump’s sentencing on hold, his lawyers are pushing to dismiss the case. The district attorney, Alvin L. Bragg, is opposing the effort.

headline: How Thanksgiving Lasagna Became an American Staple
abstract: The Italian American tradition has been adapted by other immigrant families into delicious takes on the classic.
lead_paragraph: Justin Pichetrungsi is having lasagna this Thanksgiving, carrying on a tradition his parents started. But he’ll be making his from scratch. Thanksgiving was a rare day off for his parents, who ran a Thai restaurant, and they weren’t really turkey people. For the holiday, they often bought lasagna from the nearby Costco and served it with the store’s bagged Caesar salad tossed with its packaged Chinese chicken salad dressing. The spread was rounded out with a Cantonese seafood feast from a beloved local restaurant.
snippet: The Italian American tradition has been adapted by other immigrant families into delicious takes on the classic.

headline: Texas Education Board Backs Curriculum With Lessons Drawn From Bible
abstract: School districts serving more than two million elementary-school children would be able to adopt a curriculum that draws on the Bible.
lead_paragraph: Texas education officials backed on Tuesday a new elementary school curriculum that infuses material drawn from the Bible into reading and language arts lessons, a contentious move that would test the limits of religion’s presence in public education.
snippet: School districts serving more than two million elementary-school children would be able to adopt a curriculum that draws on the Bible.

headline: 22 Patrons Stuck for 2 Hours on a Pinwheel Ride in California
abstract: Two of the riders at Knott’s Berry Farm in Orange County were taken to the hospital after the malfunction on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-two patrons were stuck in midair for two hours on Monday when a ride broke down at Knott’s Berry Farm in Orange County, Calif.
snippet: Two of the riders at Knott’s Berry Farm in Orange County were taken to the hospital after the malfunction on Monday.

headline: How to Make Your Sofa Look Even More Inviting
abstract: Expert advice from interior designers on going beyond the standard two-pillows-and-a-throw treatment.
lead_paragraph: With sofas, comfort comes first. But a couch typically “occupies prime real estate” in a room, says the decorator Alexandra Pappas, 47, of Pappas Miron Design — meaning it’s worth thinking about its visual appeal, too. Of course, there’s the standard two-pillows-and-a-throw treatment but, for a truly original look, the more colors, shapes and textiles you can incorporate, the better. Take the former Vogue editor Diana Vreeland’s famous Manhattan living room, designed in 1957, where the same red floral fabric covered the walls, curtains and sofa, which was filled with contrasting cushions, including ones that she’d needlepointed herself; or the eclectic Milanese library of the writer and botanist Umberto Pasti, whose couch is strewn with Moroccan carpets and an antique cheetah skin. For practical advice on creating a similarly inviting layered effect, we spoke to a handful of interior designers who have perfected the art.
snippet: Expert advice from interior designers on going beyond the standard two-pillows-and-a-throw treatment.

headline: Could Trump Install Gaetz Without Senate Approval? A Recess Appointment Primer.
abstract: The Constitution allows the president to circumvent the Senate and put appointees in place while the chamber is in recess, a loophole created back when Capitol commutes involved long treks by horse.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s rapid move to stock his administration with loyalists, some viewed with skepticism even by members of his own party, is testing both his grip on Senate Republicans and the boundaries of executive power.
snippet: The Constitution allows the president to circumvent the Senate and put appointees in place while the chamber is in recess, a loophole created back when Capitol commutes involved long treks by horse.

headline: Nordic Countries, Eyeing Russia, Dust Off Their Crisis Advice
abstract: Sweden, Finland and Norway have recently updated their advice for citizens preparing to survive war and other crises, wary of Ukraine’s grinding fight against Russia.
lead_paragraph: The last time that Sweden updated the crisis preparedness advice it distributes nationwide, Russia had not yet launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine and Sweden had not joined NATO in response.
snippet: Sweden, Finland and Norway have recently updated their advice for citizens preparing to survive war and other crises, wary of Ukraine’s grinding fight against Russia.

headline: A Bizarre Love Triangle Playlist
abstract: Sabrina Carpenter, Loretta Lynn and SZA sing about all the points on a love triangle.
lead_paragraph: Today’s playlist is all about one of popular music’s favorite shapes: the love triangle.
snippet: Sabrina Carpenter, Loretta Lynn and SZA sing about all the points on a love triangle.

headline: Civil War Toll Much Worse in Confederate States, New Estimates Show
abstract: An analysis of newly released 19th-century census records offers more insight into the conflict’s costs.
lead_paragraph: Faded ink. Inconsistencies. Fires. The deadliest conflict in American history, the Civil War, also had some of its worst-kept records, making the true number of casualties seem forever elusive.
snippet: An analysis of newly released 19th-century census records offers more insight into the conflict’s costs.

headline: Inching Toward a Fusion Energy Future
abstract: A handful of start-ups are racing to usher in an era of near-limitless fusion energy, but big questions remain.
lead_paragraph: In 1952, a machine with a funny name and a funny shape was zapped to life in the mountains of New Mexico. The Perhapsatron, a doughnut-shaped glass tube surrounded by magnets, was one of the world’s first nuclear fusion devices. Its name reflected the feelings of its creator, James Tuck, a scientist at Los Alamos National Laboratory: “Perhaps it will work and perhaps it won’t.”
snippet: A handful of start-ups are racing to usher in an era of near-limitless fusion energy, but big questions remain.

headline: Trump Taps Wall St. Executive Howard Lutnick for Commerce Secretary
abstract: The billionaire executive and leader of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s transition team will be charged with promoting U.S. industry and overseeing technology controls on China.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump picked Howard Lutnick to serve as commerce secretary on Tuesday, tapping a billionaire Wall Street executive for one of the most prominent and increasingly powerful economic positions in the federal government.
snippet: The billionaire executive and leader of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s transition team will be charged with promoting U.S. industry and overseeing technology controls on China.

headline: Vehicle Hits Students Outside Elementary School in Central China
abstract: A man drove a car into a group of people near an elementary school in Changde, a city in Hunan Province, on Tuesday, injuring multiple students.
lead_paragraph: A man drove a car into a group of people near an elementary school in Changde, a city in Hunan Province, on Tuesday, injuring multiple students.
snippet: A man drove a car into a group of people near an elementary school in Changde, a city in Hunan Province, on Tuesday, injuring multiple students.

headline: TKTS to Open Booth in Philadelphia, Hoping to Boost Local Theaters
abstract: The first domestic TKTS outpost outside New York comes at a time of rising concern about ticket prices and theater economics.
lead_paragraph: TKTS, the landmark theater discounter that has been a Times Square mainstay for 51 years, is expanding to Philadelphia at a time when regional theaters are struggling and ticket costs are a persistent cause of consumer concern.
snippet: The first domestic TKTS outpost outside New York comes at a time of rising concern about ticket prices and theater economics.

headline: Did the Trump Prosecutions Damage Democratic Credibility?
abstract: Many voters may have thought Democrats were the authoritarians.
lead_paragraph: On election eve in Philadelphia, Oprah Winfrey issued this warning to a rally full of Kamala Harris supporters: “If we don’t show up tomorrow, it is entirely possible that we will not have the opportunity to ever cast a ballot again.” Winfrey was once one of the most trusted figures in American public life. And yet most voters did not believe her. The next day, Donald Trump won the popular vote.
snippet: Many voters may have thought Democrats were the authoritarians.

headline: Unexpected Turns in Trump Election Cases Raise Questions About Their Durability
abstract: Canceled oral arguments in one case and a judge’s recusal in another have added to questions about the future of four state cases against Donald J. Trump and his allies.
lead_paragraph: Election interference cases against President-elect Donald J. Trump and his allies are moving forward in Georgia and Arizona, but recent complications in each case have fueled speculation about whether the prosecutions are in more fragile shape than they were before Mr. Trump won the election.
snippet: Canceled oral arguments in one case and a judge’s recusal in another have added to questions about the future of four state cases against Donald J. Trump and his allies.

headline: ‘Tammy Faye’ Musical to Close After Failing to Find Broadway Audience
abstract: Well-reviewed in London but poorly received in New York, the musical with an Elton John score will end its run on Dec. 8.
lead_paragraph: “Tammy Faye,” a new musical about the scandal-wracked singing televangelist, will close on Broadway after an unexpectedly short run, a major disappointment for a costly and ambitious show that picked up some good reviews in London but was poorly received in New York and failed to find an audience.
snippet: Well-reviewed in London but poorly received in New York, the musical with an Elton John score will end its run on Dec. 8.

headline: Richard V. Allen, Reagan’s First National Security Adviser, Dies at 88
abstract: His tenure was short: He was forced to resign after $1,000 in cash was found in a safe in his former office, even though the Justice Department cleared him of wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: Richard V. Allen, President Ronald Reagan’s first national security adviser, who was forced to resign after less than a year in office, much of it under a cloud of controversies that muted his voice in contributing to foreign and military policies, died on Saturday in Denver. He was 88.
snippet: His tenure was short: He was forced to resign after $1,000 in cash was found in a safe in his former office, even though the Justice Department cleared him of wrongdoing.

headline: Trump to Watch Latest SpaceX Launch With Elon Musk
abstract: The president-elect’s appearance in Texas demonstrates the growing closeness between the two billionaires, and Mr. Musk’s increasing influence in Mr. Trump’s orbit.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump is traveling to Brownsville, Texas, on Tuesday to attend a test launch of SpaceX’s next-generation rocket in another show of solidarity with Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, who helped catapult the former president back to the White House.
snippet: The president-elect’s appearance in Texas demonstrates the growing closeness between the two billionaires, and Mr. Musk’s increasing influence in Mr. Trump’s orbit.

headline: Son of Norway’s Crown Princess Is Arrested on Suspicion of Rape
abstract: Marius Borg Hoiby, the stepson of Crown Prince Haakon of Norway, was arrested on Monday. His lawyer denied the accusation and said his client was cooperating with the authorities.
lead_paragraph: The eldest son of Norway’s crown princess was arrested on suspicion of rape on Monday, the authorities in Oslo said, the latest accusation in a scandal that has roiled the country’s royal family.
snippet: Marius Borg Hoiby, the stepson of Crown Prince Haakon of Norway, was arrested on Monday. His lawyer denied the accusation and said his client was cooperating with the authorities.

headline: How Trump Can Earn a Place in History That He Did Not Expect
abstract: The president-elect has a starting point: the plan for a two-state solution that he put out in January 2020.
lead_paragraph: Does Donald Trump’s return to the presidency herald the end of U.S. pressure on Israelis and Palestinians for a two-state solution? Not necessarily: It depends on which Donald Trump occupies the White House.
snippet: The president-elect has a starting point: the plan for a two-state solution that he put out in January 2020.

headline: For Russia, Nuclear Weapons Are the Ultimate Bargaining Chip
abstract: The Ukraine war has not only shattered millions of lives and shaken Europe. It also has inured Washington to the use of nuclear threats as leverage.
lead_paragraph: On the 1,000th day of the war in Ukraine, President Volodymyr Zelensky took advantage of Washington’s new willingness to allow long-range missiles to be shot deep into Russia. Until this weekend, President Biden had declined to allow such strikes using American weapons, out of fear they could prompt World War III.
snippet: The Ukraine war has not only shattered millions of lives and shaken Europe. It also has inured Washington to the use of nuclear threats as leverage.

headline: House Republicans Target McBride With Capitol Bathroom Bill
abstract: G.O.P. lawmakers whose leaders have pressed to roll back transgender rights around the country moved to bar Sarah McBride, the first transgender member of Congress, from women’s rooms on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: When Representative-elect Sarah McBride, a Delaware Democrat, won her race for the House this month, becoming the first openly transgender person elected to Congress, she knew she would face attacks from hard-right Republicans over her identity.
snippet: G.O.P. lawmakers whose leaders have pressed to roll back transgender rights around the country moved to bar Sarah McBride, the first transgender member of Congress, from women’s rooms on Capitol Hill.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Ukraine hits Russia with U.S. Missiles
abstract: Plus, the Scandinavian band that’s big in Asia.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s military used American-made ballistic weapons known as ATACMS yesterday to strike into Russia for the first time and hit an ammunition depot in the Bryansk region of southwestern Russia, officials said.
snippet: Plus, the Scandinavian band that’s big in Asia.

headline: Asheville Gets Drinkable Tap Water Back, 53 Days After Hurricane Helene
abstract: There was a sense of relief in the city, though some residents said they were still afraid to drink the water.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Watts, 57, barely followed the incremental updates on his city’s water distribution system after Hurricane Helene knocked it offline in September. All he knew was that life in Asheville, N.C., had become more difficult and dirty.
snippet: There was a sense of relief in the city, though some residents said they were still afraid to drink the water.

headline: At 17, She Just Passed the State Bar of California
abstract: Sophia Park is believed to be the youngest person to pass the California State Bar Exam, besting the previous record-holder: her older brother, Peter.
lead_paragraph: Sophia Park, 17, and her family huddled around her laptop one evening this month as she entered her details onto the State Bar of California’s website and clicked “Check pass list.”
snippet: Sophia Park is believed to be the youngest person to pass the California State Bar Exam, besting the previous record-holder: her older brother, Peter.

headline: Physicist Who Made Superconductor Claims Exits University of Rochester
abstract: Journals had retracted papers on superconductors that worked at room temperature and materials science that involved Ranga Dias.
lead_paragraph: Ranga Dias, a physicist who faced a public reckoning over accusations of research misconduct, is no longer employed by the University of Rochester, a spokeswoman for the institution said Tuesday.
snippet: Journals had retracted papers on superconductors that worked at room temperature and materials science that involved Ranga Dias.

headline: Trump Plans to Nominate Dr. Mehmet Oz to Oversee Medicare, Medicaid and Obamacare
abstract: The celebrity physician would run the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, a powerful agency in charge of programs that cover more than 150 million Americans.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Tuesday that he would nominate Dr. Mehmet Oz, the author and former television host, to serve as the administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, a powerful agency that oversees health insurance programs covering more than 150 million Americans.
snippet: The celebrity physician would run the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, a powerful agency in charge of programs that cover more than 150 million Americans.

headline: The Onion’s Bid to Acquire Infowars Has Gotten Messy
abstract: A hearing is scheduled for Monday to review the auction process, which is being contested by a losing bidder associated with Alex Jones, the Infowars founder.
lead_paragraph: There was a merry triumphalism to the announcement last week that The Onion, a satirical outlet based in Chicago, won an auction to acquire the conspiracy site Infowars out of bankruptcy.
snippet: A hearing is scheduled for Monday to review the auction process, which is being contested by a losing bidder associated with Alex Jones, the Infowars founder.

headline: A Nostalgic Biden Fades Out of the Picture in Talks With World Leaders
abstract: As he made his final appearance at global gatherings, including at the Group of 20 summit in Brazil, President Biden lobbied for his foreign policy goals even as leaders shifted attention away from him.
lead_paragraph: World leaders at the Museum of Modern Art in Rio de Janeiro were discussing plans to confront poverty and war when President Biden acknowledged the obvious — this was most likely his last time attending such an elite meeting.
snippet: As he made his final appearance at global gatherings, including at the Group of 20 summit in Brazil, President Biden lobbied for his foreign policy goals even as leaders shifted attention away from him.

headline: Two Apartment Buildings Were Planned. Only One Went Up. What Happened?
abstract: New York City is dealing with its worst housing shortage in decades. The diverging fates of two developments offer a window into the crisis.
lead_paragraph: New York City is dealing with its worst housing shortage in decades. The diverging fates of two developments offer a window into the crisis.
snippet: New York City is dealing with its worst housing shortage in decades. The diverging fates of two developments offer a window into the crisis.

headline: Sean Combs’s Lawyers Argue That Seizure of Notes From Jail Was Unjust
abstract: Lawyers for the music mogul objected at a hearing to prosecutors viewing handwritten materials from their client’s cell after a sweep of the Brooklyn jail where he is being held.
lead_paragraph: Sean Combs appeared in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday as his lawyers objected to the prosecution’s use of handwritten notes found inside the music mogul’s jail cell, arguing that his rights had been violated when they were turned over to prosecutors.
snippet: Lawyers for the music mogul objected at a hearing to prosecutors viewing handwritten materials from their client’s cell after a sweep of the Brooklyn jail where he is being held.

headline: Ukraine Fired U.S.-Made Missiles into Russia
abstract: Also, prosecutors called for a four-year freeze on Trump’s Manhattan case. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Early this morning, Ukraine’s military launched a volley of American-made ballistic missiles into Russia for the first time. The attack came on the 1,000th day of the war and less than a week after President Biden gave the Ukrainians permission to do so in a major shift of American policy.
snippet: Also, prosecutors called for a four-year freeze on Trump’s Manhattan case. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.

headline: House Race in California Is Separated by 314 Votes
abstract: The closest House race in the nation is in Southern California, where Representative Michelle Steel is trailing her challenger, Derek Tran, by a tiny margin after nearly 310,000 votes have been counted.
lead_paragraph: The contest between Representative Michelle Steel, Republican of California, and her Democratic challenger, Derek Tran, has become the tightest House race in the country, with margins hovering for days in the dozens of votes.
snippet: The closest House race in the nation is in Southern California, where Representative Michelle Steel is trailing her challenger, Derek Tran, by a tiny margin after nearly 310,000 votes have been counted.

headline: Netanyahu Offers $5 Million for Each Hostage Freed in Gaza
abstract: As he resists pressure to reach a cease-fire that would release the captives, Israel’s prime minister is now offering a reward for their freedom, while still vowing to punish anyone who hurts a hostage.
lead_paragraph: Cease-fire talks to end the fighting in Gaza are stalled. Casualties in the enclave are mounting. And the families of hostages captured from Israel in the Hamas-led attack that ignited the war have grown increasingly desperate about the plight of their relatives in captivity.
snippet: As he resists pressure to reach a cease-fire that would release the captives, Israel’s prime minister is now offering a reward for their freedom, while still vowing to punish anyone who hurts a hostage.

headline: Atmospheric River and Hurricane-Strength Storm Drenches the West
abstract: A “bomb cyclone” over the Pacific Ocean is expected to bring days of damaging winds, rainfall and blizzards to Northern California, Oregon and Washington.
lead_paragraph: A historically strong storm system with the strength of a hurricane whipped damaging winds through the Pacific Northwest overnight leading to power outages across the region. It was creating large ocean waves and ushering in a drenching atmospheric river that is expected to continue soaking Northern California.
snippet: A “bomb cyclone” over the Pacific Ocean is expected to bring days of damaging winds, rainfall and blizzards to Northern California, Oregon and Washington.

headline: As Elon Musk Moved to the Right, His Businesses Moved to Texas
abstract: The billionaire has rapidly transformed parts of the state, shocking even development-friendly officials: “It was like, ‘Voilà, Elon is here.’”
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk had long been drifting away from the political culture of California, railing against its regulations and pandemic-era lockdowns. So, four years ago, he decided to move to Texas, eager to embrace its wide-open business culture and be embraced by its Republican leaders.
snippet: The billionaire has rapidly transformed parts of the state, shocking even development-friendly officials: “It was like, ‘Voilà, Elon is here.’”

headline: Democrats Face a Series of Tests Over Support for Israel
abstract: First up is a resolution put forth by Senator Bernie Sanders, a Vermont independent who is Jewish, to deny Israel certain military weapons.
lead_paragraph: Democrats whose support for Israel has been strained by the wars in Gaza and Lebanon appear headed for a series of tests in the coming weeks over continuing to back Israel’s right-wing government and the attendant debate over antisemitism and the anti-Israel left.
snippet: First up is a resolution put forth by Senator Bernie Sanders, a Vermont independent who is Jewish, to deny Israel certain military weapons.
